bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed and Landon Reed, December 19, 1946

div1.p: Hench sends the Reeds photographs of the recent Walter Reed Memorial Association board meeting and poses questions concerning Walter Reed's residences in Mercersburg, Pennsylvania and in Washington, D.C.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed and Landon Reed, December 19, 1946
div1.opener:
December 19, 1946
General and Mrs. W. L. Reed
2810--36th Place, North West
Washington, D. C.
My dear General and Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
By separate post I am sending you some small enlargements
of the snapshots I took at the recent Board Meeting of the
Walter Reed Memorial Association. I have sent copies to Mrs. Reed
and to Blossom Reed--also to the other Members of the Board. They
were taken with a little $5 “flash” Brownie so please don't compare
them with professional photographs. I had such a grand time with
you that evening in Washington and Miss Schnurr enjoyed it so
very much. I am anxious to see her notes--I think she will be
here on a short visit soon. Your notes will be of tremendous help
to me.

It was so nice to see your mother again as I passed
through Blue Ridge Summit on my way to Mercersburg. I was anxious
to see your father's home there--I had a little trouble finding
it but Mr. Harry Cox kindly took me to what he thought was it.
I enclose a snapshot of it. According to him, it is now known as
the Hahn Place on Mount Anglewood. I sincerely hope I was not
misinformed. Would you kindly identify the photographs in the
enclosed snapshots? Should you wish an enlargement of the better
one, I should be delighted indeed to send it to you. Is the house
pretty much as it was when your father lived there, or has it
been materially changed?

I also enclose the photograph of the apartment house in
Washington which General Kean identified as the one in which your
family and his family lived in 1902. As I remember, your family
lived on the first floor on the left in the photograph. General
Kean thought you had lived on the second floor. Is this the right
apartment?

Mrs. Reed, I believe you and I share a fondness for
candy; and, having lived half of my life in Pittsburgh. I have always
loved Reymer's candy. I tried to order a box to be sent to you
before Christmas, but received word that they were no longer accepting
mail orders until after Christmas. Will you please accept in due
General and Mrs. W. L. Reed
-2-
December 19, 1946
time this little token of my very deep appreciation for all
that you have done and with belated Christmas wishes.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
